Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Cross-Layer Modeling and Design of Energy-Aware Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Minimization of energy consumption is critical to developing green, sustainable technologies for cognitive radio terminals that can connect to networks that operate on different frequency bands with a variety of air interfaces. The intellectual merit of this project is a unified and coherent consideration of RF components, communication system algorithms, baseband computation platforms, and design tools, to greatly increase spectrum sharing efficiency. Dataflow methodologies are a promising candidate for the modeling, analysis and verification of cognitive radio systems. As dataflow models are abstract and platform independent, the same model can be used to generate implementations for very different devices from low-power sensor nodes to high-end mobile terminals. The key novelty is in the development of systematic methods for design, implementation, and integration of configurable RF chains, and in the development of dataflow methods for formal analysis and optimization of these new capabilities. The expected results are: (1) Energy consumption models and a design framework for computation, control and configuration of future radio devices, leveraging the investigators' existing experimental testbeds, (2) Configurable radio architectures for wide-scale cognitive access of noncontiguous RF spectrum, and (3) Design methodologies for flexible, energy-efficient cognitive wireless networks. The broader impact includes international collaboration through the WiFiUS program creating a holistic design for configurable frequency agile terminals. A novel interdisciplinary approach is enabled by the unique international team, which builds upon collaborations between experts at the Tampere University of Technology and University of Oulu in Finland, and Rice University and the University of Maryland in the US.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As Internet usage shifts from traditional desktop computers to mobile handheld wireless communications devices, there are increasing challenges to provide sufficient bandwidth for all users. Applications such as high definition video streaming are putting increasing stress on wireless communications infrastructure and the limited wireless spectrum allocated to communication systems. Recently, the concepts of spectrum sharing and cognitive radio technologies have emerged to help alleviate this limitation and are planned for advanced 5th generation wireless communication systems. However, this additional flexibility can lead to increased cost and complexity in wireless devices and highlights the need for improving the efficiency of new communication systems. An important component that affects the performance and range of a mobile wireless device is the power amplifier (PA). The power amplifier is the final analog component between the radio chip and the antenna. In order to reduce the cost of mobile handsets, equipment suppliers often use power amplifiers that have non-ideal nonlinear characteristics that can distort the signal that is transmitted. In addition, in 5G communication systems, radio transmission may occur over multiple frequencies or carriers. Because of the limited spectrum availability, new schemes for 5G will aggregate multiple carriers to provide more bandwidth to support higher data rates. These carriers may not always be adjacent to each other. This new scheme of discontiguous or separated carriers puts additional stress on power amplifier performance. The traditional method to handle this limitation is to reduce the gain of the power amplifier or to "back off." However, this will reduce the efficiency and range of the transmitted signal. A technique called Digital Pre-Distortion (DPD) can be used to create an error correction signal to mitigate PA distortion. However, these DPD schemes are usually applied to only single carrier narrow band systems. In this project we develop novel low complexity algorithms and experimental verification for DPD architectures for discontiguous carriers suitable for 5G and cognitive radio applications.

 

Intellectual Merit: This collaborative project as part of the wireless research initiative between Finland and the United States (WiFiUS) is focused on Cross-Layer Modeling and Design of Energy-Aware Cognitive Radio Networks. We demonstrated results of several digital pre-distortion schemes over the air using the WARP wireless testbed in both UHF and ISM radio bands. The block diagram of the system model is shown in one of the attached figures. The output spectrum showing the reduction in the power of the intermodulation spurious frequency (IM3) is shown in the next figure. Also the experimental apparatus showing the WARP wireless testbed node running the DPD algorithm and connected to a spectrum analyzer is shown in the photo. The novel sub-band DPD scheme developed in this project can provide 20 dB of suppression to support new low cost flexible spectrum assignments in 5G and cognitive radios.

 

Broader Impacts: We undertook a novel interdisciplinary approach that is enabled by our unique international team of U.S. and Finland researchers, which builds upon individual pair-wise collaborations between faculty and students at the Tampere University of Technology and University of Oulu in Finland, and Rice University and the University of Maryland in the U.S. Several international joint publications (U.S.-Finland) and student and faculty exchange visits were part of this project.
